displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. And who knows what we may have by then too. If you don’t need it at all at that time. The, the I was going to sugg-propose that we do the prescreening and the blood test in anticipation of doing that testing for your blood today. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that way we have at least that cooking… Family Member: Check the markers and? Doctor: Right. If the markers are positive, I think you should go on the Niraparib, the PARP inhibitor - the targeted treatment… Patient: Alright. Yeah, yeah. Doctor: If the markers are negative, then we’ll put you on that new hormone therapy study. Okay? Patient: Okay. Family Member: So sort of uh – Doctor: But if he can select out for something that might be to work from what we know right now, that’s worthwhile to me. Patient: Okay. So (clears throat)

Family Member: He goes outside. Doctor: Yes. He’s got a little color. (Laughs) Patient: If it wasn’t for this darn ankle I’d be… Doctor: I think you know what you need to do about that. You just got to ease up man. Patient: Yeah I do. Yeah. Thank you. God bless you. Family Member: Thank you. Patient: And I think the world of you, this is still rolling. I think the world of you. Doctor: Just say I need a raise. Patient: Send her to Toledo for a vacation. (Laughs) Doctor: Nice. See ya. Patient: Yeah. (Door closes)

Patient: She injected me with something. Family Member: No. No. Doctor: You’ll continue on your hormone shots every three months for the rest of your life. Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, so I’ll set that visit up for sure. Huh, and then, huh, hopefully within the next couple of weeks we’ll be able to figure out where you are and you can get started on the abiraterone. Patient: Okay. The pills that you told me to stop taking, should I go back on them? Doctor: No. You should not. You’re done. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We’re going to try a new drug, huh, that’s quite expensive, and we have to just be able to figure out if we can get it for you. Patient: Okay. Family Member: I appreciate it. Right. Patient: And how would I find out?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You were not keen on getting cut open or getting your bowels or your pee’s re-routed. Patient: I’m really not. Doctor: I know you’re not. Patient: I mean, and they want me to put the bag on. Doctor: I know they do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You would actually get two bags. Patient: F*** you sayin’? Doctor: One pee, one poop. Patient: Oh, hell, no, doc! Doctor: That’s what – this is what I’m sayin’.

Family Member 2: It’s uh essential oils. Doctor: Oh! What kind is it? Family Member 2: It’s Young Living, it’s Breathe Again. It’s one of the rollers they make. Family Member 1: She sells essential oil. Doctor: Young Living. One of our coordinators is a big person in that. And I see her sometimes on Facebook. I didn't know smell this good. Patient: Well some of it does. Family Member 1: Just bring out your little mini ones and show her. Doctor: This one’s really good. Family Member 1: She has Family Member 2: I know we're getting recorded but I'm ready for sleep. Family Member 1: C___ or C___ Family Member 2: I’ll give you my card.

Patient: Yeah that’s fine. Family Member: That’s fine because I could set up an appointment with him to just kind of go over things and I don’t know when they’ll want him to start. Doctor: When your control is better. Family Member: Do we decide that or do we come see you again first? Doctor: You decide it with Dr. F___ but don’t rush into it. Patient: Right. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: What do you do? Family Member: I’m a physical therapist, but I manage the rehab department at C____. Doctor: What’s your phone number? For whoever is going to take a phone call. Family Member: You’re giving all the phone calls to me (Laughs) Doctor: Let me just write down who you are.

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Some of it is sometimes that blood test that’s fluctuating could be better. Usually it doesn’t. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So we would definitely have to repeat that again. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because if you’re seven and remained positive, then you’re eligible for one study versus another study. Patient: Oh. Doctor: So I think that’s what we were you know were tentatively sort of earmarking for you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, both _____ or myself, I think you as well agree - Patient: Yes. Doctor: Did I put words in your mouth? Patient: Nope.

Patient: You know? J___ will probably ask more. (Laughs) Doctor: As I expect her to. (Laughs) Patient: She’s my little warrior. Doctor: Huh. I know. Patient: You know? It was you know I, I can of expected it. I was worried about hearing that but you’ve got to do what you’ve got to do. Doctor: You’ve got to do what you’ve got to do. And you know we could always switch course elsewhere. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I mean this is. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I have to say, though, that you look better today post radiation than before we started. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You were really uncomfortable. You know? Patient: Yeah. And now I did have some.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Don’t go there. I’m trying to ask a good question – Doctor: Okay. Patient: - that I’m trying to feel and understand and I know you have an answer as to if that’s going down, why am I feeling this pain again? Has the chemo kind of lessened up again that’s why we need a second and a third one to really go after them? Doctor: Yeah. Well it’s not lessened up, it’s just this does not do anything. This is a nice false sense of like hmm it’s going in the right direction. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But you have plenty more cells we got to kill. Patient: Yeah, yeah, okay. Doctor: So that’s one. Normally it takes three to sometimes four doses… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …for it to work and that’s true for most medicines. It takes three to four doses of anything for anything to work. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You don’t have enough in your blood stream to do anything.

Patient: Sure. Doctor: …of the pelvis and targeting ah systems that they have is very accurate. As accurate as we can get with the current state-of-the-art, but… Patient: What would they be targeting? Doctor: They would be targeting the bed where the prostate was removed. Patient: Oh just around – around the urethra and th - Doctor: Correct, correct. Patient: - seminal vesicles and (patient talking over doctor) Doctor: So when we talk about side effects there’s always the potential – Patient: Right. Doctor: - for you know unintended injury to things in that area like the bladder, the urethra, ah the colon which - or the rectum which sits right behind. Patient: Sure. Doctor: You can have things like blood in the urine. You can have problems with healing in that area. That’s why we don’t automatically refer people immediately…

Patient: Oh yeah. That’s the best case scenario. Doctor: …then the cancer is giving us a break and you can deal with your… Patient: Right other stuff. Doctor: …neck issue and spine and penis issue too. Laughs]] Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Now that we’re on tape let’s document this. It’s real. You have to face it. Family Member: We’re being nice to them and saying here, look at this. & DOC Laughing]] Patient: Oh. Doctor: Okay so first of all let me go ask Dr. L____ if he can see you today. Patient: Okay, oh yeah? That would be nice. Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Let me go check with him. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Well you know I ordered some more yeah. Doctor: Oh you got a refill. Patient: I haven’t been doing better. Doctor: Okay but stay with them because what it does it’s not gonna be immediate, it allows the blood flow to go into the penis. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And take it uh like twice a week. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Uh don’t wait you know for having, having sex with somebody, Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: take it so that uh, it’s like medication you would take on a regular basis… Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Take that so that it keeps the blood flow going.

Patient: Yes. Healthcare Professional: Mhmm. Doctor: Okay. Alright so I think we’re gonna have to contact you back (pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: …correctly for you then we have to switch to a different medicine. Okay. So go ahead and stop the Casodex. Okay? Patient: The - The Casodex I don’t – don’t take the Casodex? Doctor: Do you have enough for the next month or so? Patient: Right now I have about, I probably got about a week left of that before they re… Doctor: Okay perfect. Don’t refill it. Patient: Okay, but just take… Doctor: Until I figure this out. Patient: But just take the rest of those?

Patient: I threw up times. I have Doctor: I think we should refer him to GI because I really don’t know what uh… Patient: What? Doctor: I have no idea. I’ve never seen that. Patient: Yeah me either. Doctor: And we can’t see it on the CAT scan either. So I don’t know what to make of it. Patient: What? Doctor: We’ll, we’ll talk to the radiologist. Patient: Wait a minute, wait a minute Dr. B____, you got me scared and everything. If I can’t see it on the CAT scan. Doctor: Why are you scared? Patient: I’m not well well God is good. Doctor: It’s a good thing. Patient: Yes.

Patient: But just take the rest of those? Doctor: And then I’ll have you come back next week. Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. (pause doctor whispering) Patient: So finish these off and don’t refill. Doctor: Right. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And I’m going to add on a testosterone level today so that will give me information by tomorrow. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. (pause8sec) Patient: Yes. Healthcare Professional: Yes that’s today’s. (pause6sec) Doctor: The good news is you’re not feeling any different. Right?
